H0.text: Artificial turf, made of fibers that resemble real grass, uses less water than natural grass in sports stadiums.

H1.text: It produces more heat, which is the most likely benefit of artificial turf—fibers that resemble real grass—used in some sports stadiums instead of natural grass.

H2.text: It releases less moisture, which is a likely benefit of artificial turf in sports stadiums that use fake grass instead of natural grass.

H3.text: It absorbs more carbon dioxide, which is a benefit of artificial turf made of fibers that look like real grass.

A4.text: It is easily maintained without irrigation or trimming.

A5.text: Artificial turf tends to retain heat from the sun and can be much hotter than natural grass with prolonged exposure to the sun.

A6.text: a study at New Mexico State University found that in that environment, water‑cooling of artificial turf can demand as much water as natural turf.

A7.text: Artificial turf has been shown to contribute to global warming by absorbing significantly more radiation than living turf and, to a lesser extent, by displacing living plants that could sequester carbon dioxide through photosynthesis;
